name: Billionaires
bio: Despite losing an historic antitrust ruling last year the Microsoft cofounder is still the wealthiest man in the world. The software company is appealing the ruling, and Gates is moving on: He has returned to the programming trenches as the company's chief software architect.

name: Billionaires
bio: "We have embraced the 21st century by entering such cutting-edge industries as brick, carpet, insulation and paint," Buffett told his Berkshire Hathaway shareholders this year. "Try to control your excitement." More exciting is the holding's company's stock price in the last year, up 14.4%.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Microsoft cofounder has sold millions of the software giant's shares to finance his wired-world investment strategy: a portfolio of dozens of Internet, media and technology companies. Despite breaking out on his own, almost a third of Allen's wealth still stems from his remaining stake in Microsoft.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last fall the founder of the world's second-largest software company looked like he might become the world's richest man, but Oracle stock has since plunged. Ellison still has enough in the bank to pay for his high-profile, high-risk boat and plane adventures.

name: Billionaires
bio: 80 family members from three clans share an 80% interest in Henkel KGaA, maker of everything from adhesives to dish soap and producers of the Persil and Fa brands. Henkel, which has stakes in Clorox, Ecolab and a joint venture with Dial, posted record net profits of over $440 million on revenues of $11.2 billion in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: High-energy investor who searches out undervalued stocks saw some of them become even less valuable this year. The fortune: Prices plummeted on Internet picks Priceline.com and Amazon.com as well as holdings like Motorola and Compaq. Lucky for him, these are small pieces of a big pie. The biggest slice, his 3.9% of Citigroup, accounts for half his fortune and was up 12% since last year. Passions: Long walks near his weekend desert retreat; watching CNBC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Sam Walton (d. 1992), founder of Wal-Mart store chain, now world's biggest retailer. Jim is now chief executive of Arvest Group, a collection of community banks.

name: Billionaires
bio: In a year when most stock market returns have been dismal, the dozen or so Sainsburys who share in the fortune have reason to cheer. Sales at the eponymous family grocery business increased 6%, and the market has responded generously to the ongoing restructuring. Credit goes to nonfamily member and J.Sainsbury plc chief exec Sir Peter Davis. Meanwhile David Sainsbury, continues to focus on his political career, most recently as minister of science.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Sam Walton (d. 1992), founder of Wal-Mart store chain. Rob helped plan 1970 IPO, and has been a director since 1978. Now serves as chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: The daughter of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton (d. 1992) shares in family's massive stock holding. An active horsewoman, she lives on a Texas ranch and avoids publicity.

name: Billionaires
bio: With children Susanne and Stephan, owns 50% of luxury car maker BMW inherited from late husband Herbert. BMW had record sales of $31 billion in 2000. Other assets: 19% of newly listed smart card maker Gemplus, half of pharma and chemical producer Altana and other investments.

name: Billionaires
bio: He inherited the Microsoft chief executive post from his pal Bill Gates just in time to deal with the company's slowing growth. Long known for being the company cheerleader, Ballmer now focuses on strategy and leaves the administrative tasks to Microsoft's new president, Rick Belluzzo.

name: Billionaires
bio: While some of Hong Kong&#39s superrich suffered a slump in their companies&#39 stock prices, the Kadoories&#39 two flagships, Hongkong and Shanghai Hotels and CLP Holdings Ltd., held steady over the past year. However, the Kadoories failed to win support from city planners to redevelop a popular luxury hillside, where else? Kadoorie Avenue. The board thought the houses, built in the 1940s, had historical value.

name: Billionaires
bio: Still the richest person in France. Despite limited -- but growing -- pressure to reform L'Oreal's ownership structure, Bettencourt remains adamant about keeping most of the company in private hands to ensure "stability." L'Oreal's wildfire growth may force her hand one day soon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Anschutz made his money in oil, then added billions by branching into rail and telecom. He's now buying movie theater chains and sports teams.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Started selling matches, fish, pens, Christmas cards and other items by bicycle when a teenager. Business was really born when furniture was added (1947) and the first catalog printed (1951). Today it is known as furniture-giant IKEA. The fortune: Ownership of IKEA, with $8.6 billion in revenues last year, is divvied up into trusts and distributed to Kamprad’s 3 sons to avoid taxes and keep control. Passions: Cycling.

name: Billionaires
bio: China and Europe are pointing fingers at Li, who's known as "Superman," calling him an anticompetitive oligarch. Yet that didn't stop Queen Elizabeth from knighting him, nor China's rulers from prompting him to invest in its newly listed oil and gas company, PetroChina. Li's moneymaking abilities appear undeterred. In addition to substantial holdings in conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa, last year's reverse takeover of Canada's Renaissance Energy turned ten-year-old investment in Husky Oil-now called Husky Energy-into a $1.5 billion stake for him.

name: Billionaires
bio: A pending divorce isn't slowing down the 78-year-old Viacom chairman. He's on a nationwide book tour promoting his autobiography, "A Passion to Win," published by his media conglomerate's Simon & Schuster subsidiary.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Barbara Cox Anthony, one of two sisters who inherited vast media empire started by father James M. Cox. Today Cox Communications owns 16 daily newspapers (incl. flagship Atlanta Constitution), cable systems (6 million subscribers), radio and television stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulk of fortune lies in real estate developer Sun Hung Kai Properties. Looking ahead to China's entry into the WTO, the Kwok brothers plan to invest in property and Internet technology in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Shenzhen. Their Internet arm, iAdvantage, will put $20 million into a new company that intends to lay 10,600 miles of submarine cable for Internet communication between Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan. Never mind that parent company Sunevision's stock price is down more than 82% since last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Latin America's richest man has holdings in telecom, retailing and financial services. Now the region's biggest telecom player through holdings in Telmex and America Movil, Slim went on a buying spree south of Mexico's border this year, acquiring outfits in Ecuador and Brazil. He's also picked up stakes in U.S. retailers like OfficeMax, Circuit City and Borders. A Texas jury stung him with $454 million in damages for breach of contract over CompUSA franchises in Mexico, but the judge reduced it to $121 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: France&#39s virtuoso dealmaker continues to build his LVMH luxury-goods empire, adding Donna Karan and Emilio Pucci to its labels this year and inking a still pending deal with De Beer&#39s to open retail stores. But Arnault&#39s Internet venture Europe@web continues to disappoint. With plans to merge the Internet group's content with the new 3G mobile telephone system on hold, this estimated half-billion-dollar investment has about as much sparkle as a day-old glass of Moet & Chandon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bertarelli&#39s pharmaceutical company, Serono, posted sales of $1.2 billion last year, but it wants more. Serono is itching to sell its acclaimed Rebif multiple sclerosis drug in the U.S., where competing MS drugs racked up $1 billion in 2000 sales. Patent laws have kept Rebif ($254 million in non-U.S. sales last year) out of U.S. pharmacies. An accomplished sailor, Bertarelli is also funding a $55 million effort to win the America's Cup in 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: The college dropout founded the world's largest computer seller using a direct sales method, but now he's slashing prices to goose revenues.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: The wealthiest man in Italy was elected prime minister for the second time in May. His first stint lasted only 7 months. Has yet to resolve the conflict of interest between his new job and various business interests. Fortune: Through holding company Fininvest, owns a 48% stake in Mediaset, Italy's largest commercial broadcaster, which controls 63% of the market's TV advertising. Also owns 40% of banking and insurance group Mediolanum and 48% of Mondadori, the biggest publishing group, with a 38% market share of magazines sold in Italy. Passion: Owns soccer team A.C. Milan. Sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fidelity's heir-apparent tapped for the number two spot earlier this year. As president of the Fidelity Management and Research Corporation, all the company's fund managers and analysts will report to her about how they're investing the company's $908 billion in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: With John Fraklyn Mars and Jacqueline Badger Mars, three siblings who inherited food giant Mars Inc.: candy (Snickers, M&Ms, Milky Way), pet food (Whiskas), prepared food (Uncle Ben's Rice).

name: Billionaires
bio: With Forrest Edward Mars and John Franklyn Mars, one of three siblings who inherited food giant Mars, Inc.: Candy (Snickers, M&Ms, Milky Way), pet food (Whiskas), prepared food (Uncle Ben's Rice).

name: Billionaires
bio: With Forrest Edward Mars and Jacqueline Badger Mars, three siblings who inherited food giant Mars Inc.: candy (Snickers, M&Ms, Milky Way), pet food (Whiskas), prepared food (Uncle Ben's Rice).

name: Billionaires
bio: Swedish milk-packaging tycoon Gad Rausing passed away in 2000, leaving his fortune to his wife and three kids, Kirsten, Joern and Finn. All three are nonexecutive directors of packaging giant Tetra Laval. Sister Kirsten is a racehorse breeder. Uncle Hans is another member of the Billionaires list (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: The former financial analyst for Frito-Lay founded EchoStar 1980, and now boasts 5 million subscribers through his dish network. Sued Rupert Murdoch after failed 1997 merger; now he and Murdoch are both pursuing GM's DirecTV unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turner used to be Time Warner's largest individual shareholder. He now owns less than 4 percent of AOL Time Warner.

name: Billionaires
bio: The head of News Corp. sees the company's future in the stars, not on the Internet. Doggedly pursuing a deal with General Motors to buy Hughes Electronics, owners of DirecTV, adding more satellite services alongside News Corp.'s Sky Global Networks.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Hans Rausing is back in business after a five-year hiatus. He is an investor and adviser to Ecolean, which makes a new form of eco-friendly packaging already available in China, Europe and South America. The fortune: Rausing reportedly sold his 50% stake of Tetra Laval, a world leader in food packaging, to his brother Gad (now deceased) for $7 billion in 1995. Passions: Spinning around his Sussex, England home in one of his vintage cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Software magnate with global ambitions whose flagship Wipro, India's largest listed IT company, debuted on the New York Stock Exchange last October. Remains bullish despite an 84% drop in Wipro's market cap since its high in February 2000, and the slowdown in the U.S., Wipro's largest market. The fortune: Owns 84% of the company founded by his father in 1945 to make cooking oil, a division that still exists. Passions: Self-confessed workaholic and recluse. Graduated from Stanford last year after dropping out 35 years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Del Vecchio, who spent much of his childhood in an orphanage and worked in a factory, is founder and chairman of $2.2 billion (2000 sales) Luxottica Group, the world's largest designer and manufacturer of high-quality eyeglass frames. The fortune: Owner of Ray-Ban and U.S. optical chain LensCrafters, Luxottica bought retailer Sunglass Hut in February for $462 million. Del Vecchio sold 2.3% of the family holding last year, bringing stake down to 69%. Also has a personal stake in Unicredito, Italy's third-largest bank. Passions: Sailing on his yacht; tennis.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Extremely discreet (and extremely successful) Spanish entrepreneur, founder of $2.2 billion (revenues) fashion retailer Inditex. The fortune: Best known for its Zara brand, the makers and retailers of moderately priced stylish clothes, which went public in May. He sold 26% for $2 billion. Passions: Keeps a very low profile. He has three children, reportedly owns a horse-jumping circuit and part of a soccer league-and refuses to wear ties.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: The U.K.'s richest landowner, also known as the Duke of Westminster, continues to prosper thanks to a steady increase in land prices. The fortune: While the bulk still comes from the prized 300 "golden acres" in London, the Duke's commercial and residential real estate holdings in North America and Asia account for about 13% of his fortune. After work: Philanthropy. The Duke matched the Prince of Wales' $700,000 donation to help farmers hit by the foot-and-mouth crisis. He also gives away $1.4 million annually through his Westminster Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his longtime accountant running MGM, Kerkorian has turned his attention to other things: In January he dumped half his 33 million DaimlerChrysler shares after suing the company over its floundering 3-year-old Chrysler merger.

name: Billionaires
bio: The luxury goods business continues to be kind to Francois Pinault, who built his family's local lumber company into a $23 billion (2000 sales) retailing empire called Pinault-Printemps-Redoute. While he's been hailed as a "white knight" for blocking rival Bernard Arnault's efforts to buy Gucci, life is not all rosy for Pinault's holding company, Artemis, which has at least $3 billion in debt. He also faces legal troubles, including a California suit alleging fraud.

name: Billionaires
bio: The discount trading pioneer saw fortune plunge along with the market in the last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his brothers, runs $3.1 billion (revenues) Mohammed Abdulmohsin Al-Kharafi & Sons, a contracting group. Its latest venture: developing a 236-millionsquare-foot mega-resort on Egypt's Red Sea coast, adjacent to an airport the group is building. Project cost is estimated at $2 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eschewing risk for a change and concentrating on safer investments, his hedge fund group gained a modest 4 % last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite this real estate baron's prediction that residential real estate prices would remain stagnant, Lee has been spending a large part of this past year buying up shares in his own group of companies, spending a reported $147 million. A small investment in fellow billionaire Richard Li's Pacific Century CyberWorks lost $320,000 in one day, but Lee claims to be unfazed: "I just pretended that I spent it on a midnight dim sum."

name: Billionaires
bio: The founder of home builder KB Home and financial services giant Sun America is now focused on "venture philanthropy," reforming urban education systems.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Sall, cofounded software maker SAS Institute in 1976. Even though the two have long been adamant about keeping the N.C.-based company private, an IPO is said to be on the horizon.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Son came within a hair of being the richest man in the world in February last year, with a fortune peaking at $76 billion before the collapse of the Internet bubble pummeled the share price of Softbank. But things are looking up. Softbank recorded a 430% increase in profits to $300 million on sales of $3.2 billion. The fortune: 37% of Softbank, which in turn owns large chunks of Yahoo, E-Trade and other net ventures. Armed with $760 million in cash from selling Yahoo shares near the top of the market, Son's Internet empire building continues apace. However, questions about the wisdom of his purchase of the troubled Nippon Credit Bank remain. Passions: Golf. He has an artificial golf course in the basement of his house.

name: Billionaires
bio: Benetton, who lost his father at age 10,  got his start in 1955 when he founded a small sweater company with sister, Giuliana. He continues to run the now $1.8 billion (2000 sales) fashion empire. Other holdings: Autogrill, food catering group with $250 million in 2000 sales; Autostrade, Europe's largest publicly listed motorway network and Grandi Stazioni, which operates Italy's largest railway stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: After his father Jay died in 1999, Pritzker took control of the family's Hyatt hotel chain. With his uncle Robert (see), also owns jet manufacturer Galaxy Aerospace, other holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1997 the great-grandson of the founder of BASF orchestrated the sale of  pharmaceutical firms Boehringer Mannheim and DePuy Inc. to Roche for $11 billion. His stake netted him $4.4 billion. Retired, he now lives in Bermuda with his fourth wife, Heidemarie.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Intel co-founder gave half his fortune this year to fund a charitable foundation. Now entering retirement, he's giving up his Chairman Emeritus title.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Cofounder and cochairman of $5.5 billion (sales) software giant SAP. The fortune: In a weakening market, SAP is updating its image by moving to the Internet. mySAP.com, an Internet business portal which provides software to make e-businesses work, accounted for 20% of revenues last year. Passions: Avid golfer and world-class sailor, owns a golfing resort in South Africa. Through SAP will sponsor New Zealand's bid for the America&#39s Cup.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Cisneros is increasingly a must-have contact for U.S. businesses in Latin America. An incessant networker, Cisneros seems to know everyone, including the Pope and the Dalai Lama. Although less popular at home because of ties to corrupt former president Carlos Andres Perez, Cisneros was still the person former president George Bush contacted to help set up a meeting with the current Venezuelan president Hugo Chavez in March. The fortune: His Cisneros Group has joint ventures with AOL Latin America and DirecTV. His Univision is the fastest growing television network in the U.S.  The Group also has lucrative deals with Coca-Cola and Pizza Hut.  Passions: Fishing and baseball. He and his wife are also major collectors of Latin American art. Their foundation promotes education and the protection of indigenous people in the Amazon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Walter Haefner is 90, but he's still got the stomach to handle tech stocks. To wit:  His 21% stake in Computer Associates is worth about $2.3 billion less than it was a year ago. Still, his children needn't worry: The rest of the family fortune-some $2 billion-is safely invested in Amag, a new car dealership that owns an exclusive right to sell VWs and Audis in Switzerland. Haefner also raises racehorses in Ireland and the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Taking his hip retail clothing chain Hennes & Mauritz into new markets, he opened 90 stores in 2000 and plans to open another 100 this year. The fortune: Bumped up holdings slightly last year to 36.5% of shares. Profits were down 16% last year because of costly expansion in U.S.; stock is down 27%. But Persson believes strongly in his product-much of his wardrobe is from H&M. Passions: The Mentor Foundation, a charitable organization that aims to reduce substance abuse in youth.

name: Billionaires
bio: With older brother Samuel Irving (Si) Newhouse, inherited sprawling magazine and newspaper empire Advance Publications. Si runs Conde Nast magazine group; Don oversees newspapers (Newark "Star-Ledger," Cleveland "Plain Dealer").

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Donald, inherited sprawling magazine and newspaper empire Advance Publications. "Si" runs Conde Nast magazine division: "Vogue," "Vanity Fair," "New Yorker."

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Eldest son of Werner Otto, founder of $2 billion (revenues) Otto Versand, which began in 1949 as a 14-page catalogue offering 28 styles of shoes and is now the world's largest mail-order company. The fortune: With his father and four siblings, owns 65% of Otto Versand, over 50% of home furnishing chain Crate & Barrel, U.S. catalog retailer Spiegel and a $1.5 billion real estate portfolio in the U.S., Canada and Germany. Passions: Committed environmentalist, has established a foundation for the protection of water resources in eastern Europe and northern and central Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to founder of insurance giant Allianz. Retired in Switzerland, he oversees a fortune based on stakes in insurance, mining and chemical companies, a retail chain, property rental and leasing, and a sizable portion of Swiss restaurant and hotel chain Movenpick

name: Billionaires
bio: The trend-setting House of Chanel -- founded by the Wertheimers' grandfather in 1923 -- has managed to maintain Coco's innovative flair without damaging its hard-earned reputation as the classic brand. They are co-owners of the company. The brothers also dabble in wine, owning Chateau Cannon and Chateau Rausan Segla.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Dassaults made their name in aviation, and continue to build top-rated civilian and military jets, including the Falcon executive-jet series and the Rafale fighter-bomber. But Dassault Group's computer assisted design (CAD) business is the family's most valuable asset these days. The clan has also gotten into the high-tech venture capital game, plunking down $143 million for startup projects in Silicon Valley, Asia and Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Simmering sibling rivalry dating back to his father's death in 1965 when Gunter took control of Tchibo Holding AG group erupted, resulting in his retirement in January. He had led $4.7 billion (sales) Tchibo for nearly 36 years. The fortune: The family continues to share ownership of Tchibo, which sells coffee and consumer items in its coffee shops; a lucrative 26% share of skin care products maker Beiersdorf AG and 63% of Reemtsma, the world's fourth-largest cigarette maker. Passions: An avid racehorse fan, owns a trotter stud farm in Schleswig-Holstein.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Owner of Fast Retailing, whose Uniqlo brand casual-clothing stores saw sales grow 126% to $2 billion in the half year that ended in February. Is expanding into sporting goods and opening stores in the U.K. The fortune: Longer-term plans include moves into food and furniture retailing, as well as expansion into the U.S. market. Fast Retailing's discount sales, using direct shipping from Chinese factories to retail outlets in Japan, have lowered Japan's Consumer Price Index during the past year. Passions: Reading books and playing golf.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 70% of privately held Gerling Konzern, one of the world's largest industrial insurers. Not active in the business. Lives in Switzerland where he heads a research institute specializing in industrial psychology and pursues his passionate interest in the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: How much bigger can a fund company get when it has $908 billion under management? By growing its brokerage operations, a business that now handles $242 billion in online and traditional trading accounts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family patriarch John Latsis made his fortune in shipping and can still be found entertaining British royals aboard his lavish yacht, "The Alexander." His son, Spiro, a banker, has shifted the family fortune away from shipping and into banking. A small tanker fleet still flies the Latsis colors, but the bulk of the extended family's wealth comes from its ownership of EFG Bank Group, an international commercial and private banking consortium based in Switzerland.

name: Billionaires
bio: His eponymous financial data terminals are standard at Wall Street firms, but he's now receiving more attention for his run for mayor of New York City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 7-Eleven chains in the U.S. and Japan, plus supermarket chain Ito-Yokado. While Ito-Yokado is stumbling, 7-Eleven continues to dazzle. This year Ito finally received approval to open the Ito-Yokado bank, a branchless consumer bank that is expected to threaten the old banking order with ATMs installed in all 8,600 7-Eleven outlets in Japan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known as one of Venezuela's "old money" families, the Mendozas shun publicity and jealously guard their Polar brewing and bottling empire's secrets. Focus remains on core food and beverage businesses. Polar President Lorenzo Mendoza (grandson of the founder), recently completed the $400 million acquisition of Mavesa, a local food processor, part of a five-year, $1.7 billion expansion program.

name: Billionaires
bio: Creator of web auction site Ebay. Took company public 1998, now concentrating on using his new wealth to support charitable causes such as education, housing and health care.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation of Oppenheimers to head diamond empire DeBeers, chairman Nicky, 56, led a successful $19 billion bid to take the group private this year. The deal gives his family a 45% stake. Plus they have 4% of mining giant Anglo American, down from 8% last year. He also inked a deal with LVMH (see Arnault) to open DeBeers retail stores. His father, legendary diamond baron Harry Oppenheimer, passed away last August. Passion: His luxury game park, which he wants to turn into "the premier eco-tourist destination in Southern Africa."

name: Billionaires
bio: Supersecretive Irving clan maintains stranglehold on Atlantic coast of Canada through an integrated empire of oil, timber, paper, trucking and shipping holdings. They are also the biggest landowners in Maine. This year finished a $650 million upgrade to Canada’s biggest oil refinery in Saint John, New Brunswick. Also bought a Toronto tissue paper mill from Procter & Gamble. Its Cavendish Farms is the world’s second-biggest potato processor, turning out one billion pounds last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: With father Perry and brothers Sid and Ed, the Bass family is still enhancing oil fortune made by Perry's uncle Sid Richardson. Early investors in Disney, but money in troubled Warnaco not faring as well.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nike boss Knight may be more inclined to dip into his fortune for his alma mater again now that the University of Oregon is withdrawing from the Worker Rights Consortium. Knight had canceled plans for a $30 million gift when the labor rights group criticized Nike's use of foreign labor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited Carnival Cruise Lines from father Ted (d. 1999) expanded it. Now the world's biggest cruise operator with 45 ships. Owner pro basketball's Miami Heat.

name: Billionaires
bio: Irvine Co. chief didn't expand too far into Silicon Valley, holding steady with still-rich Orange County properties.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his three sons, Karl-Erivan, Georg and Christian, shares ownership of $24 billion (sales) food retailer Tengelmann Group, Germany's sixth-largest employer, and 57% of A&P supermarkets in the U.S. Tengelmann has been restructuring in an effort to offset the effects of a slack German retail market and increased industry consolidation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brains behind fading Beanie Babies; looks ever wiser for reinvesting toy profits in hotels.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Weston fortune, split among eight siblings, straddles the Atlantic. Galen runs George Weston Ltd., Canada’s biggest grocery chain (which just bought Bestfoods from Unilever for $1.8 billion). Brother Garry recently retired from London-based Associated British Foods, following a stroke. Galen’s private holdings also reach into high-end clothing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With father Perry and brothers Lee and Ed, the Bass family still enhancing oil fortune made by Perry's uncle Sid Richardson. Early investors in Disney, but money in troubled Warnaco not faring as well.

name: Billionaires
bio: Huntsman Corp., which he founded in 1982, is now a diversified chemical manufacturer with $8 billion in sales. He recently sold a chunk of equity to Bain Capital for $600 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Leonard and Ronald control the cosmetics concern started by mother Estee in 1946. Today Estee Lauder Co. controls 45% of the prestigecosmetics industry with such brands as Clinique, M.A.C., Aveda, Bobbi Brown, and Stila.

name: Billionaires
bio: Though Perot handed over day-to-day control of data management company Perot Systems to his son, Ross Perot Jr., the two-time presidential contender remains chairman. Perot Jr. also runs Hillwood, a Dallas-area real estate development company.

name: Billionaires
bio: The woman: All eyes are on the heiress to Ted Arison's Israeli operations, a mother of four with limited business experience. The fortune: Looking to sell Housing & Construction in favor of a more streamlined banking and telecom conglomerate. A chunk of Carnival Cruise shares were transfered to her ownership this past year. Passions: Brainchild behind ?Matan,? Israel's answer to the United Way.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former chairman of TWA offered $1.1 billion for the bankrupt airline in March, but a federal judge favored the $742 million bid by American Airlines parent AMR. Now he's talking to Las Vegas-based National Airlines which he hopes to turn into an outlet for his Lowestfare.com travel site, a web concern he tried to take public in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mobile phone service dominates the fortune. Despite $16 billion raised by Turkcell&#39s IPO last year, the company is currently valued at only $3.2 billion. The Karamehmets? 43% is worth 82% less than in the IPO last June. Potential new competition foreshadows more rough riding ahead.

name: Billionaires
bio: The hotel, real estate and media tycoon turned over the reins of his vast empire to his sons two years ago, but the Kerry Group is seen largely as directionless without the patriarch. Kuok's South China Morning Post is beset by quarrels over coverage of the mainland, and profit at Kerry Properties was down 40% last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Two brothers head Votorantim, Brazil's largest private conglomerate, which is heavily into pulp and paper, cement and aluminum. Revenues last year were $2.7 billion. Antonio recently told the Brazilian press he expects a loss for the group in 2001 due to Brazil's energy crisis.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cellular pioneer sold debt-strapped McCaw Cellular to AT&T for $11.5 billion in 1993. Later founded wireless company Nextel and broadband provider Nextlink; now looking to the stars with risky satellite-based "Internet in the sky" venture Ico-Teledesic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Japan's slot-machine king. Last year he bought 50% of the Las Vegas-based casino management company Valvino Lamore (owned by veteran casino entrepreneur Stephen Wynn) for $230 million. Faulty parts caused a temporary stumble in sales of his slot machines last year, but things are now back on track.

name: Billionaires
bio: Schmidheiny is a full-time philanthropist who has poured $175.8 million into his Avina foundation since 1994. The foundation funds socially and environmentally responsible development projects in Latin America, Switzerland and North America. Schmidheiny inherited his nest egg from the family's Holderbank cement company fortune-founded by grandfather Ernst; managed by brother, Thomas (see)-most of which he's invested in blue-chip stocks. He's also a patron of modern art, with a collection estimated at half a billion dollars.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Screws and fasteners for construction form the underpinnings of this Renaissance man's wealth. His secret: delivering the goods directly to the workers and mechanics who need them. The fortune: Sales and net profits last year at the $4.5 billion (sales) Adolf Wurth Group grew by 25% and 44%, respectively. Passions: Maintaining and adding to his 6,000-piece collection of 20th century art featuring works of Picasso, Miro and Max Beckmann housed in a museum  within company headquarters and a brand new one in Schwabisch Hall near Stuttgart.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Retired from Vivendi board soon after it took over family-controlled Seagram. Vivendi wanted its Universal Pictures but not liquor business. Disgruntled Charles looked into buying back the booze, which was eventually sold to Diageo and Pernod. The fortune: Aside from Vivendi shares still controls Israeli conglomerate Koor Industries. Passions: Dedicated to philanthropy in Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio: After making his first billion in the music business, Geffen started a new Hollywood studio, Dreamworks SKG, with partners Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg. Now he's investing in distressed companies, like health care firm McKesson HBOC.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Bud Walton, brother of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton. Ann and sister Nancy Walton Laurie inherited Wal-MArt stock after father's death in 1995. With husband Stan Kroenke owns pro basketball's Denver Nuggets and current hockey champions Colorado Avalanche.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited Seagram from father in 1971. Son Edgar Jr. shifted focus from beverages to entertainment. Sold to Vivendi for more than $30 billion. Now focusing on philanthropy. Awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom as president of the World Jewish Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Companies tremble when Martin Ebner buys up their shares. The Swiss investor has been called a "renegade" for his aggressive brand of shareholder advocacy. But Ebner doesn't always get his way. Last year his efforts to parlay a 16% stake in Roche into a board seat sputtered. Ebner's BZ Group investment vehicle has since dumped an estimated $2.75 billion of its Roche shares. His efforts to land himself a board seat at the Credit Suisse Group, in which BZ Group has a 10% stake, have also stalled.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable pioneer wisely chose cash over stock upon AT&T's $58 billion purchase of MediaOne last year. Still invests via family's Pilot House Associates.

name: Billionaires
bio: This real estate mogul who owns Shin Nihon Kanko is also the largest shareholder in Japan Airlines. Refusal to rely on debt has insulated him from the bad-loan disasters that befell many of his colleagues in the Japanese real estate business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Promise, Japan's third-largest consumer finance company, which has been selected as a successful case study by Harvard Business School. His only son, Hideki, the largest shareholder of the company, died of lung cancer in April at age 47.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Home Depot cofounder now serves as the company's chairman, stars in its television commercials. As company expands rapidly, Marcus focuses on philanthropy: He has given $45 million to help children with brain disorders.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs a commercial real estate empire founded by his father. This private company is expected to go public within three years. It is also moving heavily into the Japanese REIT (real estate investment trust) market. Brother Minoru has a similar business, but large debts keep him out of the billionaire's club.

name: Billionaires
bio: The junk-bond financier's portfolio has been bolstered by his stake in Golden State Bankcorp, but he's still struggling to turn around wounded cosmetics giant Revlon.

name: Billionaires
bio: With husband Donald, opened the first Gap store in 1969 in San Francisco, added or acquired brands including BabyGap, Old Navy, Banana Republic. The chain is grappling with growth pains and falling profits: The Fisher family is no longer in day-to-day control after departure of sons William and Robert from executive ranks, but Donald remains chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of the Adecco temporary-employment agency, Foriel-Destezet is one of a growing number of French tax expatriates living in Britain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kipp sold the last 5% of his Massa chain of German department stores in 1994 but kept the underlying real estate. Owns four luxury hotels in Switzerland and buildings in New York. Retired, he lives at the Hotel Tschuggen in Arosa, Switzerland, one of his five-star hotels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Charles and David run Koch Industries, the $35 billion oil conglomerate founded by father Fred. Their legal tangles continue with estranged brother William, who accused the company of stealing oil from federal lands. Koch Industries recently settled a case brought by the U.S. Justice Dept. over a 1995 benzene mishap in its Corpus Christi refinery; the company agreed to pay a $20 million fine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Charles and David run Koch Industries, the $35 billion oil conglomerate founded by father Fred. Their legal tangles continue with estranged brother William, who accused the company of stealing oil from federal lands. Koch Industries recently settled a case brought by the U.S. Justice Dept. over a 1995 benzene mishap in its Corpus Christi refinery; the company agreed to pay a $20 million fine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Leonard and Ronald control the cosmetics concern started by mother Estee in 1946. Today Estee Lauder Co. controls 45% of the prestigecosmetics industry with such brands as Clinique, M.A.C., Aveda, Bobbi Brown, and Stila. Chairman of RSL Communications, which recently filed for bankruptcy.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of Chicago financier Henry Crown (d. 1990), he oversees family investments in General Dynamics, Maytag, Vulcan Materials, among others.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Chief executive of Mediolanum SpA, Italian life insurance and fund management company that's part of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's empire. The fortune: Mediolanum's total assets under management grew 38% last year to $16.6 billion. Doris also has a 30% stake in Alboran, a young high-tech company that his son chairs. Passion: Mountain biking.

name: Billionaires
bio: He runs the fourth-generation gum empire founded in 1891 by his great-grandfather. Investors who've chewed over Wrigley's financials must like what they see: the company's stock is up 17% in the last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mexico's young television mogul. He took over Televisa, the country's biggest network in 1997 when his father died. He is clearing out papa's debt and bringing in new partners like Carlos Slim Helu (see) and Maria A. Aramburuzabala (see). The San Diego State-educated Azcarraga has also moved programming away from politics to entertainment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third son of oilman Perry Bass, but went his own way when father passed control of family fortune to brother Sid. Big investments in tax-friendly oil and gas royalty trusts.

name: Billionaires
bio: His family-run construction giant built its reputation under founder Warren Bechtel by building Hoover Dam and Oakland Bay Bridge. Revenues declined last year to $14.3 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: His family-run construction giant built its reputation under founder Warren Bechtel by building Hoover Dam and Oakland Bay Bridge. Revenues declined last year to $14.3 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Pittsburgh industrialist turned his father's coke, steel business into an investment and real estate powerhouse. He's an original backer of Silicon Valley venture capital gurus Kleiner Perkins and a donor to the Hillman Cancer Center at University of Pittsburgh.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Kamel built his empire on the strengths of banking and real estate, before venturing into media. He founded MBC (Middle East Broadcasting Center) and ART (Arab Radio & Television). The fortune: Owns a majority in Dallah Albaraka, a conglomerate that runs a regionwide Islamic banking empire and holds interests in real estate, construction and manufacturing. ART continues to be a chronic moneyloser and cash drain. Passions: Media is his love.

name: Billionaires
bio: The "Star Wars" maven made an estimated $250 million last year, almost all of it from video sales of "The Phantom Menace." No wonder the filmmaker is busy working on the next installment.

name: Billionaires
bio: The media-shy chief of Spanish language broadcasting giant Univision is countering new competition by shelling out $1.1 billion for 13 USA Networks stations, which it will convert into a second Spanish-language network. He's also getting into the Spanish-language music business through a Mexican acquisition.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bold chief of Mexico's number two network, TV Azteca. Played a key role in last year's presidential election by introducing a nightly TV debate that became the soapbox for now-President Vicente Fox. Pliego also appointed an independent overseer to the Azteca board, a gesture meant to reassure Wall Street, which views him as a tyrant uninterested in shareholder rights. Also runs wireless phone outfit Unefon and Latin America's leading specialty retailer Elektra. Likes to fly helicopters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Limited 1963, now over 2,800 stores icluding Express, Lerner NY, Lane Bryant, Henry Bendel, Structure. Recently announced plans to sell Lane Bryant, move Structure into Express division due to lagging economy. Art enthusiast.

name: Billionaires
bio: His company, Nintendo, has introduced its first portable game player in five years, the GameBoy Advance. It will soon replace its flagging Nintendo 64 players with a new disc-based player called Game Cube. Sales of portable players continue to support record profits. The outlook for its new nonportable player is less of a sure bet in the face of strong competition from Sony and Microsoft. He is the Majority owner of the Seattle Mariners baseball team, which has been leading its American League division this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Septuagenarian chairman of Cablevision Systems transforming cable company into entertainment empire: Owns pro basketball New York Knicks, hockey's New York Rangers, Clearview Cinema Group, consumer electronics chain The Wiz, the American Movie Channel and Bravo cable networks. Now negotiating for controlling interest in Boston Red Sox.

name: Billionaires
bio: Successful banker sold most of his Banco Real to ABN Amro in 1998 for $2.1 billion. Heads the remaining assets, Alfa Holdings. Plus, owns hotels, radio stations, soybean farms and a cattle ranch.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner James Goodnight, cofounded software maker SAS Institute in 1976. Even though the two have long been adamant about keeping the N.C.-based company private, an IPO is said to be on the horizon.

name: Billionaires
bio: He dropped out of college to fly Navy fighters during World War II, then sold Cadillacs. His Enterprise rental car business took off in the 1970s, his son Andrew now oversees the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Hungarian immigrant fell in love with aviation, then pooled money with Leslie and Louis Gonda to form International Lease Finance Corp. 1973. They sold to AIG in 1990, but Udvar-Hazy remains at helm. Made a major donation to Smithsonian's Air & Space Museum for a new building named for him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs property developer New World Development, whose stock price has fallen by half since last year. His private investment vehicle, Chow Tai Fook Enterprise, bought a 50% stake in upscale Sogo Department stores for an estimated $226 million. Kowtowing to China's rulers, Cheng put up $50 million to buy shares in newly listed PetroChina, the mainland's biggest oil and gas producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker, he continues as the non-executive director of his family's financial services company Schroders. He is known to be a amicable man who loves flying airplanes and shooting stags as well as spending time at his Scottish estate. With sister Charmaine and family trust, has 47% stake in Schroders PLC. The family also enjoyed a nice windfall from last year's sale of the investment banking division.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Ebay cofounder is growing into his wealth. Skoll finally moved out of the house he shared with four college buddies and into a Silicon Valley pad of his own. Also replaced 1989 Mazda with 2000 Corvette convertible. The fortune: Owns 15% of Ebay, once worth as much as $5 billion. Passions: Most treasured collectibles are Canadian silver dollars, Ken Dryden hockey card and Ebay cofounder Pierre Omidyar’s old business cards.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thomas Schmidheiny is the chairman, managing director, and owner of a controlling interest in Holcim (formerly Holderbank), one of the world's leading producers of cement, with $8.2 billion in sales last year. As the cement industry consolidates, Holcim is gobbling up companies around the world-8 last year alone. The company recently bailed out of a deal to buy Portugal's CIMPOR for $4 billion, claiming the price was too high.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the five founders of German software powerhouse SAP, trained physicist Tschira now spends his time in Heidelberg running his foundation, which is dedicated to scientific and cultural projects that capture his imagination.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Built Metro AG into the world's fourth-largest retailer, with $41 billion revenues. He owns 19%, as do the Haniel and Schmidt-Ruthenbeck families. The fortune: Metro expansion continues with a new joint venture with Tokyo's Marubeni Corp. to open stores in Japan. Passions: Although officially retired, keeps busy with his Internet and technology company, Beisheim Holding Schweiz, when not relaxing at his home in Florida.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Formula One Management and its web of companies that handle the promotion, travel and business of auto racing. In his 20s Ecclestone had a brief fling as a driver, but has profited much more from his business dealings. His official stake in the company is down to just 25%, after the Kirch Group (see) bailed out ailing muppet owner EM.TV & Merchandising’s half-share and exercised a $1 billion option for another 25%. But with a hand in every glove compartment of the business, Ecclestone is still the power broker.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout, ex-Marine, built own TV tower with $1,500: "Just trying to get a good picture." Acquired cable franchises and built Cablevisionn Industries, which he sold to Time Warner in 1996 for $2.8 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Heads Koc Holding, which celebrated its 75th year as one of Turkey's biggest conglomerates. Has interests in cars, consumer durables, energy and banking. Revenues last year were $11.7 billion. The fortune: Value of fortune tumbled 43% from a year ago because of Turkey's economic problems. Koc Holding's Energy Group partnered with Norway's Statoil for natural gas and LPG procurement and distribution. Koc is emphasizing exports in all its businesses, including its new Tofas-Fiat automobiles.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former TCI head is ready to go it alone again when AT&T spins off his Liberty Media investment vehicle 2 years after buying it along with TCI. Malone is now a major investor in Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. and is also moving into the European cable market.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of oil tycoon John D. Rockefeller. Ran Chase Manhattan bank, now concentrates on philanthropic endeavors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rowling's main holding, Omni Hotels, continues expansion despite the sluggish economy; he recently paid $65 million for William Penn Hotel in Philadelphia. He's also a large stakeholder in bankrupt Pacific Gas & Electric; an investment in Texaco is faring better.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive brothers thrive on their father's visionary investment in giant retailer Metro. They own 19%, as do Otto Beisheim and the Haniel family.

name: Billionaires
bio: Keyence, a maker of factory automation equipment, made record profits of $220 million on sales of $820 million in the year through March 2001.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicholas' wallet is $8 billion lighter this year because of Broadcom's stock dive.

name: Billionaires
bio: His real estate empire extends across Manhattan and New Jersey, but he's shrinking his other holdings: Stern sold the Village Voice and other publications two years ago; this year he sold his pet supply company.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Last year Bouygues was a front-runner to win a license from the French government for new mobile phone technology known as 3G. But he balked at the $4 billion price. Now with 3G faltering, he&#39s looking pretty savvy. The fortune: The family's traditional construction businesses are still booming, with $11 billion in sales last year. But increasingly it&#39s Bouygues&#39 telecom unit -- with a 18% share of France&#39s current wireless market -- that&#39s getting all the attention. Passions: Bouygues showed a flair for pamphleteering during the French government&#39s 3G auction process, writing critical editorials in several newspapers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, but left family business to study music, write operas. Last year, Getty publically acknowledged he had three children with a Los Angeles mistress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Also known as Kuo Tai Ming, he is as secretive as his PC and circuit board maker Hon Hai Precision Industry is successful. An early investor in China, Hon Hai reportedly derives of its 60% of its $2.9 billion in revenues from its mainland operations; profits last year were $310 million. He is reportedly looking to invest some $90 million in the optical electronic and communication sector.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of legendary wildcatter H.L. Hunt lost ground when his $940 million bid for Calgary-based Berkely Petroleum was rejected. While Middle East politics continue to rattle his long-delayed pipeline project in Yemen, Hunt Oil recently signed exclusive rights to drill in offshore area of Togo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Higher gas prices put a spark into his Kaiser Francis Oil Co., but a 75% stake in Oklahoma-based BOK Financial is where the real money is. Kaiser is a founder and supporter of the Tulsa Community Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Launched Polo in 1967 with $50,000, transformed men's clothing line into brand behemoth: Sells clothes for women and children, as well as fragrances, linens, paint and accessories. Collects antique cars and motorcycles; owns homes in New York, Colorado and Jamaica.

name: Billionaires
bio: He cofounded chipmaker Broadcom with fellow UCLA engineer Henry Nicholas; the company predicts that sluggish sales will improve this fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Best Buy electronics chain founder, whose first stores were called Sound of Music, is returning to his roots in a way: His company recently completed the purchase of the Musicland Group record store chain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Decaux founded an outdoor advertising company in 1964. With the help of two of his sons, who are now co-chief executives, Decaux has built J.C. Decaux into the third-largest outdoor advertising company in the world. The group is renowned for its arty billboards and fun new public toilet booths. The family was expected to sell almost 20% of the company in a public offering in June. Its remaining stake is still more than 70%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded software maker PeopleSoft in 1987 with $2 million nest egg; took public in 1992. Reduced role in company following 1999 stock slump; now concentrates on philanthropy, especially animal welfare.

name: Billionaires
bio: World's largest car retailer focuses solely on new cars, using fixed, "no-haggle" prices. The college dropout dismantled sports empire: sold Florida Marlins 1997, sold Florida Panthers 2001. Still owns Miami Dolphins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ingram inherited Ingram Industries conglomerate, with interests in books, insurance and barges, from her late husband. Under her watch Ingram Micro became a fixture in the PC business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish immigrant, worked as maid to Johnson & Johnson founder John Seward Johnson, then became his wife. Inherited large stake in Johnson & Johnson upon his death in 1983.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Korean immigrant founded Amkor in 1968 as a marketing arm for father's chipmaker: He bought out his father's company after 1990s Asian collapse. Kim also owns majority stake in  Electronics Boutique, a retailer started by wife, Agnes, as a mall stand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Active horse breeder inherited shares in Wal-Mart from father James "Bud" Walton. Owns pro hockey's St. Louis Blues.

name: Billionaires
bio: The shopping mall king celebrated 40 years in the business in May with his Westfield Group. Earlier this year, Westfield America agreed to lease the retail portion of New York City's World Trade Center for $420 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made infotech pioneer, Nadar's HCL group was a garage startup 25 years ago. Now it is India's biggest PC maker and provider of computer training. He is concentrating on selling high-end software and network services to the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: This drug czar owns generic drug-makers Apotex, Cangene and 41% of Barr Laboratories, which hopes to have a generic Prozac on the market by August. Fearlessly challenges big pharmaceutical companies on drug patents. Donates 20% of Apotex earnings to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left Oracle 1990, started Siebel Systems: application software for customer service, marketing and sales. Currently integrating customer relationship management software with IBM products.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Chairman and managing director of Al Rajhi Banking & Investment Corp., which operates under Islamic principles, paying no interest on deposits. The fortune: One of four brothers, he has the most active role in the banking empire and the biggest personal stake at 23%. Other holdings with family include country's biggest poultry farm, a building-materials business and real estate. He reportedly has at least 23 children. Passions: Farming.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of John Dorrance, the founder of Campbell Soup and the inventor of condensed soup. He became an Irish citizen in 1994 under a controversial Irish passport-for-investment scheme.  His siblings and fellow heirs to the fortune are still U.S. citizens.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half brother Rupert Johnson Jr., runs Franklin Resources, one of the 10 largest money managers in the U.S. Two of his sons serve in executive positions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sergio's father, Antonio, founded the Globus & Cosmos tour company in 1928 with a rowboat he used to paddle tourists around Lake Lugano. The company, run by Sergio (president) and his sons, Paolo and Fabio (in charge of U.S. and U.K. operations, respectively), now boasts its own fleet of airplanes and portfolio of exotic guided tours around the world. Estimated 2000 sales were $2.5 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The men: Monaco-based Sammy controls shipping assets, while brother Yuli runs real estate, banking and tech operations from Tel Aviv. The fortune: Romanian-born brothers mulling buyout of State of Israel's 50% stake in Zim Israel Navigation, a shipping container company. Passions: Sammy is avid modern art collector, while Yuli donates to Israeli universities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood legend made his name with hits like Jaws, E.T. and Raiders of the Lost Ark. The founding partner in Dreamworks SKG studio also a passionate archivist of Holocaust survivors' accounts.

name: Billionaires
bio: The e-commerce pioneer is under pressure from skeptical analysts, many of whom doubt Bezos' prediction that Amazon.com will turn a corner by earning a "pro forma operating profit" by this year's fourth quarter.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Owner of one of Germany's largest publishing groups, Hubert Burda Media Holding. The fortune: Titles at the $1 billion (revenues) company range from award-winning Focus business magazine to tabloid Bunte. The group is the largest provider of German content sites on the Internet. Passions: High-profile Burda founded the  Hermann Lenz Prize for German literature  and supports the Bambi Prize-Germany's version of the Academy Awards. Enjoys mountain climbing

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James C. Kellogg III, became a partner at Spear, Leeds and Kellogg in 1945; became nation's largest specialist firm on the New York and American stock exchanges. Eventually took control of the firm, passed reins to son in 1973. Sold last fall to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: A year ago he was the toast of Asia's media. No longer. Li's Pacific Century CyberWorks is being crushed by $1 billion debt incurred from last year's bewildering $38 billion acquisition of Cable & Wireless HKT; an $866 million loss; and a stock price that's collapsed 80%. Oh, and Li admitted he never graduated from Stanford University. Good thing Li's dad is Hong Kong's richest man (see Li Ka-shing).

name: Billionaires
bio: International Data Group rode the tech wave with instructional books ("Internet for Dummies"), magazines ("Industry Standard") and conferences (Macworld). Estimated sales: $3.1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The eldest of 8 children, he built barns to pay college tuition, and opened his first home improvement store in 1972. Now he's trying to fend off rapidly expanding competitors Home Depots, Lowes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cisco's chairman has lost 70% of his paper wealth since last summer.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Ferit Sahenk took over his father's Dogus conglomerate after Ayhan Sahenk died of a heart attack at age 72 in April. The fortune: Dogus Holding's Garanti Bank is the nation's largest, with assets of $15.5 billion. This year entered joint venture with CNBC to produce Turkey's first cable TV business channel.  Dogus is in negotiations with National Geographic to publish its magazines in Turkey. Passions: The Ayhan Sahenk Foundation, in cooperation with the National Olympics Committee, organized an international mountain bike competition in July 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads the family's Mashreqbank, with $6 billion in assets and a strong brand name in the U.A.E. Also owns shopping malls and other real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Don Alberto's old-time fortune stretches from insurance and retail to mining, chemicals, huge cattle spreads and 15 bullfighting rings in Mexico City. His Industrias Penoles is one of the world's largest silver producers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Blank founded Home Depot with Bernard Marcus in 1978 after the pair were dismissed by a now-defunct home improvement chain. Recently stepped down from his chief executive post.

name: Billionaires
bio: After quitting father's Toyota dealership in 1982, forced to sell his computer for cash. Overwhelming response to his ad in "Chicago Tribune" led him to buy and resell computers. Took Computer Discount Warehouse public in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kristiansen's 100% family-owned Lego toy company-famed for its interlocking plastic bricks-had a terrible year in 2000, reporting a $121 million pretax loss. The drop was attributed, in part, to a global slowdown in toy sales. But Lego says it was also overly optimistic with its expansion plans following a banner year in 1999. Kristiansen, Lego's chief executive and principal shareholder, has now refocused his strategy on toys, and hopes Lego's latest offering, a multimedia fantasy adventure game called Bionicle, is a hit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wales' richest man. A year after selling his Newbridge Networks to French phone giant Alcatel for $7 billion, Matthews is already deep into his next venture. He started March Networks, which develops Internet-linked telephones and voice-recognition systems. He's also broken ground on second world-class hotel and golf complex outside Ottawa to complement the Celtic Manor golf resort he owns in his native Wales.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year opened $50 million Ripley’s Aquarium in the Great Smoky Mountains resort town of Gatlinburg, Tenn. Owns 38 other Ripley’s sites in 9 countries. Also bought 20 radio and 3 TV stations in Canada. His Palm Springs retreat has original decor of previous owner, Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former money manager for the Bass family, Rainwater struck out on his own in 1986. Early investments in oil and gas are paying off big this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: He owns pro basketball's Minnesota Timberwolves, but an NBA suspension prevents him from attending games or going to the team's offices until the end of August.

name: Billionaires
bio: He earned a "vulture" reputation for buying distressed properties, then reselling them to flush buyers. But even as real estate prices have shot up in recent years, his REITs haven't stopped buying.

name: Billionaires
bio: The WWII veteran sold Slim-Fast, a nutritional supplement company, to Unilever for $2.3 billion last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Holds large stakes and board seats at Coca-Cola and Convera, but best known for running media-centric investment bank Allen & Co. His annual powwow in Sun Valley for media titans also helps raise his profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and former chairman of Cifra, the Mexican retail store in which Wal-Mart now has a large stake. The group is now called Walmex. Arango has retired from day-to-day operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Smart banker, even savvier investor. Bozano sold his Banco Bozano, Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano (see Botin) last year for a reported $550 million. But his nearly 20% stake in regional jetmaker Embraer looms larger, worth a recent $1.14 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Britain's best-known brand, Branson could use a little help marketing himself these days. His fortune is down $1.5 billion since Forbes put him on our cover last year. Profits at airline Virgin Atlantic fell 59% last year to $62 million, because of high fuel prices and stiff competition. A deadly wreck derailed the U.K. train industry, including Virgin Trains. Plus he lost his very public bid to operate the national lottery in the U.K. Virgin Mobile is still in the early stages, but has inked some important deals with SingTel, Australia's Cable & Wireless (see Richard Li), and, most recently, Sprint in the U.S. For fun: Taking time out from his daredevil adventures this year to travel with his daughter during her year off before medical school.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former grocery bagboy made his money buying out supermarkets, then took stabs at e-commerce in the last few years. Hasn't abandoned retail, though: his Yucaipa investment vehicle invested in KMart this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: San Antonio-based Butt continues expanding his H-E-B Grocery chain south of the border with recent store-opening in Tampico, Mexico. A third-generation grocer, Butt owns 285 stores in Texas and Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Gap heir branched off from the family business to found investment outfit Pisces but still holds a significant stake in the retailer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Paychex payroll business with $3,000 in 1971; now handles the books for over 350,000 clients. Active in New York State politics as well as drug and teen pregnancy prevention programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Hallmark had a busy year, spinning off its cable properties as publicly held Crown Media and making plans to sell most of its film library to Crown for $600 million. Some shareholders have sued to stop the sale, accusing Crown of agreeing to an inflated price.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former computer science professor launched Qualcomm 1985, patented third-most-popular wireless communication technology. Active philanthropist, gifts to UC San Diego and New Bedford Whaling Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: A granddaughter of Campbell Soup founder John T. Dorrance, who invented  process to produce condensed canned soup. Malone holds stakes in Campbell, sits on the board, and is an active horse breeder.

name: Billionaires
bio: London-based Mittal heads the world's fourth-largest steel group, which includes $5.1 billion (revenues) Ispat International. Ispat's stock has tumbled 65% in the last year. Meanwhile, performance at privately held steelmaker Ispat Karmet in Kazakhstan continues to improve.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Former Foreign Trade Ministry official took over the assets (but not the debts) of two Soviet-era foreign trade banks in 1992-93. Bought control of metals giant Norilsk Nickel and oil company Sidanko in lopsided privatization auctions in 1995. Served as deputy prime minister in 1996-97. Invested with George Soros in telecommunications holding company, Svyazinvest in 1997. The fortune: Even after the crash of the ruble crushed his banks, Potanin still controls Norilsk Nickel, as well as big oil and telecom stakes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a shipping manager, he went to school for 3 years to become a doctor before quitting to sell ties at a store in Milan. After stints designing for Cerruti, Ungaro and Zegna, he sold his Volkswagen to start his own label. Armani, who barely speaks English, has built it into a $1 billion brand, with an estimated $163 million in profits last year, and 260 stores. He also owns a chunk of Luxottica and sits on its board (see Del Vecchio). Younger sister Rosanna is his right-hand woman, while niece Roberta, daughter of his late elder brother, Sergio, deals with the many celebrities and is considered his likely successor. Next up: Armani Casa, an exclusive range of housewares.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Richard Peery, bought cheap Silicon Valley farmland in the 1960s. The partners are now one of the area's biggest landlords, with some 10 million square feet under management.

name: Billionaires
bio: Young Birla runs the Aditya Birla group, a $6 billion (assets) global commodities empire, named after his late father. Has joint ventures with AT&T in telecom and Sun Life of Canada in financial services.

name: Billionaires
bio: When Ferrero was marrying his secretary in 1962, he reportedly warned her: "Think hard about the kind of man you are marrying, one who can only speak the word 'chocolate'." Not much has changed for this workaholic who founded and still runs Ferrero Chocolates. The fortune: The intensely private company announced $1.4 billion of sales and $88 million in profits in 1999. Passions: Chocolate, church.

name: Billionaires
bio: Handed off daily oversight of business last year but still maintains control: recently courted, then spurned, buy-out offers from global wine giants. Wife Barbara Banke now CEO after Hewlett-Packard veteran Lew Platt stepped down in June.

name: Billionaires
bio: While tech stocks have sunk, sunglasses have been in the clouds: The stock price of Jannard's Oakley has nearly doubled in the last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half brother Charles Johnson, runs Franklin Resources, one of the 10 largest money managers in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Campbell Soup executive worked for, later bought, Iams Petfood company. Sold to Procter & Gamble for $2.3 billion in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: This no-nonsense executive, who was recently knighted, took over his father's popular grocery stall in 1957 and a year later opened the family's first self-service shop with 3 checkout counters. In 1967 he took the group public and has since achieved an unbroken 34-year record of sales and profits growth.  The fortune: Owns an estimate 39% of William Morrison Supermarkets, the U.K.'s sixth-largest supermarket chain and one of its most consistent performers. Passions: Family, work.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Arrillaga bought cheap Silicon Valley farmland in the 1960s. Partners are now among the area's biggest landlords, with some 10 million square feet under management.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Don Gregorio" has an eye for recession-proof industries. With Argentina's economy stumbling, the value of the family's consolidated energy, food processing and financial services portfolio grew a healthy 20%.

name: Billionaires
bio: The North Carolina native made his fortune in banking.

name: Billionaires
bio: "The Donald" is as busy as ever, developing former railyards on Manhattan's West Side. On the other end of city his new residential tower that dwarfs the United Nations building is nearing completion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: As a competent and honest industrial tycoon, Bogdanov stands out in Russia. The fortune: He has run Surgutneftegaz, the country's third-largest oil company, since the Soviet era, investing steadily in his business, raising productivity and accumulating $3.6 billion in spare cash.

name: Billionaires
bio: A committed Buddhist and a shrewd real estate investor, Chen delisted his flagship Nan Fung Textiles back in 1989 and rode the Hong Kong real estate boom. But unlike most, Chen seems to have weathered the Asian crisis. He bought more than 12% of developer Sino Land - owned by fellow billionaire Ng Teng Fong - at a bargain price and continues to bid for prominent properties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with partner Jay Van Andel, started direct-sales giant Amway. Company now has $5 billion annual sales. DeVos owns NBA's Orlando Magic, backs school-voucher movement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Brazil's second-largest food retailer, Grupo Pao de Acucar, which posted record profits of $175 million on revenues of $4 billion last year. Daughter Ana Maria heads marketing and has been reported as a potential successor. Abilio is an obsessive athlete; reportedly runs, swims or lifts weights several hours a day.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Funai Electric is the world's largest producer of VCRs. It is threatening other Japanese electronics companies by producing a range of electronics products cheaply in China, including DVD players, printers and TVs. Profits reached a record $100 million last year on sales of $1.2 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: He took over his father's broadcasting company in 1981, and moved into satellite television several years later. He sold his United States Satellite Broadcasting Company to General Motors' Hughes Electronics in 1999; the company is now on the block itself.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Samsung Group. His Samsung Electronics weathered the world electronics slowdown with a 31% rise in sales and an 89% jump in net income last year but might not be so lucky in 2001. The electronics unit is embroiled in a dispute with shareholder activists over last year's sale of a motor subsidiary and how its debt should be paid. He's also drawing flack for putting his son at the head of the electronics unit.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Kim Magness, two sons of TCI founder Bob Magness (d. 1996), inherited stock hoard now worth billions thanks to TCI-AT&T merger. Brothers shun publicity, breed cattle. Gary engaged to Sarah Siegel, head of women's lingerie company SoLow.

name: Billionaires
bio: His net worth has risen along with the stock price of his Mitchell Energy & Development. The 3 hotels and 17 buildings he owns have also brought new life back to his native Galveston, Tex.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Israel's version of Bill Gates. Programmed Check Point Software's Internet security software with two friends in an unair-conditioned apartment. Marked 9-hour shifts at the computer by lining up empty Coca-Cola bottles. The fortune: Holds 11% stake in the now $15 billion (market cap) firewall and cybersecurity firm. Sales Almost doubled last year to $425 million. Love Bug and Anna Kournikova virus scares helped. Passions: Loves spinning so much he installed a gym in the offices. Attended this year's company Purim party dressed as cofounder Marius Nacht (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Rescued Morrison Knudsen from bankruptcy 1996, now newly named Washington Group is in for its own bankruptcy filing after botched acquisition of Raytheon's engineering and construction unit. Other assets still running strong: railroads, mines.

name: Billionaires
bio: After working through college repairing vending machines, Berg forged a career in Silicon Valley real estate first as a loan processor, then a mortgage broker. He's now one of the area's most powerful landlords, and his Mission West Properties real estate trust escaped last year's tech wreck unscathed.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Campbell Soup founder John T. Dorrance, who invented process for producing condensed canned soup. Bennett now develops real estate in Arizona.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former president of Enron, Kinder broke out on his own in 1996 and gambled on natural gas. He now owns 20% of Kinder Morgan, Inc., which controls 30,000 miles of pipeline delivering 10 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Jerome Kohlberg and George Roberts, started quintessential LBO firm Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts. They cemented their reputations as the barbarians at the gates in the RJR Nabisco merger in 1989. These days Kravis is frequently spotted in the Hamptons while Roberts is harder to find in California Bay area.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Marriott Hotels founder Willard Marriott (d. 1985), who started root beer stand in 1927, first Marriott hotel in 1957. Now more than 2,000 properties worldwide: Richard is chairman of Host Marriott, real estate arm of empire spun off in 1993.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billie Joe (Red) McCombs started out selling used cars in 1958. Holds a large stake in Clear Channel Communications, the radio company he started in 1972 with Lowry Mays, but focuses most of his attention on his Minnesota Vikings football franchise.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of cybersecurity firm Check Point Software, programmed the original code and fetched the soda (see Schwed). Media-shy Nacht still serves on the executive board. Trained by Talpiot, an elite division of Israeli army. Now lives in Tel Aviv with wife and child.

name: Billionaires
bio: Broke away from dad's real estate business and started Danaher Corp. in 1982 with brother Steven Rales. Created manufacturing conglomerate: tools, components, process-environmental controls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Broke away from dad's real estate business and started Danaher Corp. in 1982 with brother Mitchell Rales. Created manufacturing conglomerate: tools, components, process-environmental controls.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Jerome Kohlberg and Henry Kravis, started quintesential LBO firm Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: One of Colombia's oldest and most influential bankers, Sarmiento Angulo has recently turned his attention to the telecom sector, selling his Cocelco wireless company to Bell South last year for $370 million. The fortune: Owns 98% of Grupo Aval, a banking conglomerate with a $800 million market cap. Also heavily invested in land and long-distance telephones. Passions: Avid rider of all-terrain vehicles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dallas-based investor owns interests in businesses ranging from chemicals and waste management to titanium metals and steel rod manufacturing. Recently settled dispute with two daughters who accused him of using trust funds for political contributions they opposed.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sobrato started as a residential broker in Palo Alto in the 1960s, then ventured into Silicon Valley commercial projects with Carl Berg. The two parted ways, and Sobrato now runs the business with his son, John Michael, overseeing 11 million square feet of commercial space and 470 acres of undeveloped land.

name: Billionaires
bio: Timber tycoon with holdings in Papua New Guinea, central Africa, Brazil, Russia and Malaysia: He has environmental groups denouncing him. He's been accused of everything from unauthorized logging to blowing up coral reefs. His other big move lately has been to buy up several newspapers, possibly because paper complements lumber, or perhaps because he feels he can control the news that way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three years ago the Excel Communications founder merged his telemarketing company with Teleglobe. Now he owns shares in BCE, a Canadian outfit that bought out Teleglobe earlier this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Unlike his mentor, the fallen oligarch Boris Berezovsky, Abramovich has stayed out of the political limelight, though last year he was elected governor of the arctic region of Chukotka (inhabited by 79,000 Eskimos). He lost his parents as a child, dropped out of college. The fortune: Accumulated his wealth through a series of inside deals in the Russian oil industry and helped found oil giant Sibneft, now Russia's fifth-largest oil company. In 2000 he took a major stake in Russian Aluminum, the world's second-largest producer. He also has 49% of ORT, a Moscow-based television company.

name: Billionaires
bio: A master of the steam table buffet, Bellon transformed his family's small Marseilles-based ship catering business into a global food service powerhouse with $10.5 billion in annual sales. Bellon's Sodexho Alliance bought out its U.S. partner, Marriott, in a $1.1 billion deal intended to broaden its North American footprint.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Fourth-generation banker heads Banco Santander Central Hispano, Spain's biggest bank in terms of assets ($305 billion). The fortune: Net profits rose 43% to $2 billion last year, partly due to new acquisitions in Latin America. Current strategy: controlling costs to bolster share price. Passions: President of the Fundacion Botin, which aids drug abuse prevention. Fishing, hunting, golfing.

name: Billionaires
bio: AOL founder closed purchase of Time Warner creating media behemoth. Also owns Hawaiian real estate firm and pineapple ranch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Broadcast.com cofounder sold out to Yahoo, protected fortune with derivatives. Now overly-passionate owner of pro basketball's Dallas Mavericks.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former Soros fund manager now concentrates his energies on his own Duquesne Capital Management, founded in 1981.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ford family patriarch and grandson of Henry Ford gave up chairmanship in 1999 in favor of son William Jr. Now Ford's largest single shareholder and owner of Detroit Lions.

name: Billionaires
bio: M.D. founded Hospital Corp. of America with father, instrumental in guiding company through Medicare billing fraud investigation. Expanding firm abroad, added UK hospitals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Benesse Corp., his correspondence education firm, has insulated itself from Japan's shrinking population of school-age children by increasing its stake in  the U.S.-based language-education firm Berlitz International to 98%. Aiming to profit from Japan's aging population, he is also expanding into nursing-home care.

name: Billionaires
