bio: With her sister, Marilyn Carlson Nelso, she steers the marketing, travel and hospitality conglomerate built by her father Curtis Carlson (d. 1999). Marilyn is the titular head of the company; Barbra heads the family foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Built his fortune in supermarkets. Now chairs ICA Ahold, a joint venture with supermarket giant Royal Ahold. He is also playing the role of shareholder activist at several Norwegian-based companies. The fortune: Owns a 20% stake in ICA Ahold through his holding company Canica. Plus a 4% holding in Storebrand, Norway's largest insurer; 3% in Orkla, which has a stake in brewer Carlsberg; and 42% of Steen & Strom, a real estate company that owns shopping centers in Oslo and other urban centers. Passions: Reportedly spends time in churches lashing out against corporate greed and preaching about business ethics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lifelong retailer became chief executive of Kohl's in 1978. Now serves as chairman, keeps busy with charitable causes such as children with multiple disabilities.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Wharton grad started building his empire with $60 million he received for a contact lens design in 1971. He later sold his Metro Mobile cellular phone company to Bell Atlantic for $2.6 billion; now he and his family hold a large stake in natural gas distributor Southern Union.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turning from power to pigskins: Sold his energy producer Cogen Technologies to Enron for $1.5 billion, reinvested in new NFL team for his hometown of Houston.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her sister Barbara Carlson Gate, runs the marketing, travel and hospitality conglomerate built by their father Curtis Carlson (d. 1999). Curt officially handed control of the company to Marilyn in 1998; she then split the company into two.

name: Billionaires
bio: The woman: The youngest granddaughter of Prada founder Mario Prada, she and her husband, Patrizio Bertelli, took over the family-owned luxury goods manufacturer in 1978. Since then, they've turned it into a fashion powerhouse, acquiring Jil Sander, Helmut Lang and shoemaker Church & Co. The fortune: Family owns 100% of the privately held group, which posted revenues of $1.4 billion last year. An initial offering is expected later this year.
title: Owner, Fashion Designer

name: Billionaires
bio: As boss of Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, Alekperov used his close friendship with the Fuel and Energy minister to muscle into lucrative oil deals around the Caspian Sea in the early 1990s. Recently, he has expanded downstream, buying refineries in Eastern Europe and the Getty gas station chain in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Founded Alfa Group in 1988 with a group of college friends. Made windfall profits on commodities trading, including a big oil-for-sugar deal with Cuba. Enlisted former Foreign Trade minister as partner. Outmaneuvered BP for control of one of Russia's largest oil fields 1999. Bought Marc Rich's commodities trading business in 2001. The fortune: major stakes in Alfa Bank, Alfa Eko and Tyumen Oil Co.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Banacci, the holding company for Mexico's second-biggest bank, Banamex. He got a windfall recently when Citigroup announced plans to buy the group for $12.5 billion in cash and stock. Harp has an estimated 10% stake. In his spare time, tools around with his baseball team, Los Diablos Rojos. He is fellow billionaire Carlos Slim Helu's cousin.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of the original founders of German software giant SAP, he now devotes his time to managing his cultural and philanthropic foundation, the H.W.& J. Hector Stiftung. In December 2000 he retired from board of directors of software company Novell.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Mexico's number two bank, Banamex. Citigroup recently announced plans to buy Banamex's holding company for $12.5 billion in cash and stock. If the deal goes through, it will be the largest acquisition in Mexican history. And Hernandez, son of a cattle rancher, will get a seat on Citigroup's board. His other project is a small, elegant chain of hacienda-style luxury hotels around Mexican resorts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs nation's largest self storage company. Big cancer advocate: funds research and patient care, gave $200 million to Minnesota cancer center in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apple cofounder continues to be renowned for role in the stylish  firm, but animated-film studio Pixar accounts for bulk of his wealth.

name: Billionaires
bio: New york native had first taste of success in 1968 when he took H. Ross Perot's Electronic Data systems public. Eclectic holdings: Home Depot, Tricon (restaurants), Unifi (textiles), Quipp (newspaper publishing); also runs Invemed Associates, his own investment bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Matte Group's tentacles touch almost every sector of the Chilean economy, from paper to banks to real estate and even a shipping port. The family scored $177 million in December when it sold its stake in Chilean long-distance carrier Entel to Telecom Italia. Some of that cash will help fund up to a billion dollars in planned investments in the paper sector over the next several years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left McCain Foods, the biggest french fry maker, in mid-1990s after quarrel with brother Harrison (see). Bought Maple Leaf Foods, Canada’s biggest pork producer. Still owns 33.5% of McCain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vietnam veteran joined billboard operator Outdoor Systems in 1984. Sold to Infinity Broadcasting in 1999; now owns stake in Viacom. Also owns baseball's Arizona Diamondbacks and basketball's Phoenix Suns.

name: Billionaires
bio: He&#39s less famous — and less wealthy — than his partner Warren Buffett, but he&#39s still an important of Berkshire Hathaway. Munger met Buffett in 1959, and soon began investing in Berkshire. He also owns big stakes in discount retailer Costco Wholesale and legal news publisher Daily Journal Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Last year the affable South African outbid fellow billionaires Bernard Arnault (see) and Nicolas Hayek (see), paying $1.8 billion for the much sought-after luxury watch group Les Manufactures Horlogeres.  The fortune: Controls an estimated 10% of Swiss-based luxury group Richemont, whose brands include Cartier and Dunhill. Reorganized his South African holding company into two groups: Remgro, which holds tobacco interests and other "old" economy investments, and VenFin, which includes telecom and other tech businesses. Passions: Golf with buddy Ernie Els.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Alexandria, Egypt, Saban moved to Israel in the 1950s, and built a tour promotion business there. He later to moved to Los Angeles, where he formed Saban Entertainment, best-known for its Mighty Morphin Power Rangers characters. Now part of Rupert Murdoch's Fox empire, he's trying to sell his stake in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: The SM Prime Holdings magnate has some of the biggest shopping malls in the Philippines and its stock is one of the stronger performers on the Philippine stock exchange. But with terrorists blowing up malls and the peso swooning this past year, there were some shivers in the stock price. The 76-year-old still goes to the office every day.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Sid and Lee, the Bass family is still enhancing oil fortune made by Perry's uncle Sid Richardson. Early investors in Disney, but money in troubled Warnaco not faring as well.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of Sankyo, a maker of pachinko, Japanese-style slot machines. The overall size of the pachinko market has been shrinking because of Japan's economic malaise. Nonetheless, his company has been able to post a modest rise in sales and profits.

name: Billionaires
bio: The lumber industry giant made his mark by buying up West Coast land cheap during the 1980s recession. He recently vowed that his Sierra Pacific Industries would stop clear-cutting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fredriksen's various shipping companies, led by Frontline, are riding a wave of profitability, spurred by high oil prices and new regulations banning older single hulled oil tankers from many ports. Frontline boasts a modern fleet of double-hulled tankers. Fredriksen's total investment of $290 million in Frontline is now worth $1.5 billion (market cap) today. Fredriksen also owns a fleet of liquefied natural gas tankers and controlling stakes in two oil exploration companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited valuable stakes in Amoco, other energy ventures from husband, John Murdoch Harbert III. Hobbies include hunting and needlepoint.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas trial lawyer struck gold in the Texaco-Pennzoil case of 1987. Estimated fee: $345 million. Made millions more handling personal injury cases.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Marriott Hotels founder Willard Marriott (d. 1985), who started root beer stand in 1927, first Marriott hotel in 1957. Now more than 2,000 properties worldwide: Several pieces spun off, but J.W. Jr. remains CEO of hotel-management arm Marriott International.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of Pittsburgh's Mellon family. Arch conservative, backed investigations into Clinton scandal, publishes conservative newspaper Tribune-Review in Pittsburgh.

name: Billionaires
bio: The retired lieutenant colonel turned telecommunications tycoon was elected prime minister of Thailand this year. He is now engulfed in charges that he concealed his assets by transferring them to his maids, chauffeurs and security guards in a bid to evade taxes. If found guilty, he faces a 5-year ban on holding elective office.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Stryker Corp. founder Homer works as Michigan architect and runs Arcus Foundation, dedicated to promoting tolerance of gays and lesbians, environmental issues and ape preservation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known to some as the "vice taipan," for his self-made fortune in tobacco and alcohol, he fended off a $500 million tax evasion suit involving his company Fortune Tobacco, but faces new accusations that he's concealed the extent of his holding in Philippine National Bank. However, Philippine Airlines, in which he has a controlling stake, has actually turned a profit for the first time since he's held it.

name: Billionaires
bio: With two siblings runs Ziff Brothers Investments, a private investment fund started with proceeds from retired father's Ziff-Davis publishing empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: With two siblings runs Ziff Brothers Investments, a private investment fund started with proceeds from retired father's Ziff-Davis publishing empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: With two siblings runs Ziff Brothers Investments, a private investment fund started with proceeds from retired father's publishing empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul often maligned for pricey forays in publishing, but sold Fast Company magazine at height of market for what may end up being $510 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Major shareholder in Caltagirone SpA, an industrial holding company with roots in concrete. Made news earlier this year when his wife was briefly kidnapped by their Filipino servant. The fortune: Owns a 52% stake in Caltagirone, the company he founded and has controlled since 1984. In addition to cement, the company has real estate and media interests.

name: Billionaires
bio: Northwestern graduate started medical instruments firm 1963, manufactures cardiovascular catheters, syringes, stents, pacemakers. Also runs Cook Group (airport services), plays in brass and percussion band.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started in 1969 with one drugstore in Montreal; the Jean Coutu Group now owns and operates nearly 500 outlets in eastern Canada and New England. Tight-fisted with suppliers but gives generously to developing countries, battered women and the homeless.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother and fellow billionaire William Fung, jointly runs private-label merchandiser Li & Fung. As chairman, Victor led revenues up 53% to $3.2 billion and profits up 51% to $111 million last year. He hopes to generate additional revenues of $300 million from new customer Walt Disney and $750 million from its $2.2 billion acquisition of rival Colby Group. In January the brothers took public Convenience Retail Asia, operator of 125 Circle K markets in Hong Kong.

name: Billionaires
bio: While brother and fellow billionaire Victor is chairman, William is managing director of the $5.2 billion (market cap) private-label merchandise giant Li & Fung. Willia is actively looking to put the company's extensive contacts on the Web, and hoping its lifung.com will woo small retailers and wholesalers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Married into Pace Foods family, bought out father-in-law in 1982. Divorced wife, sold Pace to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion in cash. Conservative investor; shuns spotlight, but drew attention when he reportedly paid $20 million to tear down six houses for a better view from his Aspen, Colo. home.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born Jonathan Harmsworth, the fourth Viscount Rothermere took the reins of his family&#39s newspaper empire, Daily Mail and General Trust and the Viscount title with it after his father's death in 1998. Youngest chairman of a FTSE 100 company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started in knitting mill at Jones Apparel, eventually bought company, now serves as chairman and chief executive. Firm's clothing lines include Jones New York, Todd Oldham and Evan Picone, plus licensing for three Ralph Lauren lines. Supports philanthropic causes like cancer research and the Holocaust Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: His videogame company, Konami, has a new hit product in the Yugio games and card series. Early this year his stock price was hit by investor skepticism over his purchase of a major chain of gyms. Kozuki's rationale: Konami aims to pioneer the field of "exertainment" by combining game technology with exercise equipment.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Quanta Computer manufactures neary one-seventh of all notebook computers sold worldwide. Look for that number to increase, since he plans to invest $1 billion to build the world's largest laptop factory in Shanghai. He's now expanding into mobile phones and intends to produce 1.6 million units this year. Despite a 50% drop in Quanta's stock price since last year, Lam is unfazed. "Recession, I don't know why people say there's a recession, we've been working overtime."

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold wholesale grocery firm to Wal-Mart 1965 for stock, currently oversees McLane Group's grocery distribution, computer software, food manufacturing. Owner of Houston Astros.

name: Billionaires
bio: The head of Dole and privately held Pacific Holdings has spent hundreds of millions buying up developer Castle & Cooke and its jewel: The Hawaiian island of Lanai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia's leading corporate raider continues to build his stake in Singapore's Hotel Properties, increasing his stake from 15% to 19%. He is likely to get a nice windfall this summer with DBS Bank of Singapore's $1 billion acquisition of his Hong Kong-based Dao Heng Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Aon insurance firm, acquired smaller units, expanding globally. Currently serves as chairman, chief executive. Director at Sears, Tribune Co., has stake in Chicago Bears.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over father's construction firm in 1979, branched into telecommunications with MFS Communications, which sold to Worldcom for $15.4 billion in 1996. A director and significant stakeholder at Level 3, the tech slide has hurt him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Stryker Corp. founder, maker of  specialty medical products. Colorado resident actively heads charitable Stryker Short Foundation she co-founded.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of Stryker founder is a company director and personally owns 10% of company, while two siblings have another 20% of firm. Active in Kalamazoo arts and education.

name: Billionaires
bio: He runs FlightSafety, the world's largest pilot-training firm, which he started in 1951. Ueltschi took the company public in 1968, and sold to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of John T. Dorrance, who invented process for condensed soup and bought Campbell Soup from uncle in 1914. Grandchildren together still control nearly 50% of Campbell. Charlotte active donor, including $20 million to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Woo resigned from the family's Wheelock & Co. and in 1997 made a failed bid to become Hong Kong's first chief executive. The family still owns 60% of the shipping and real estate company. Just last year Woo succeeded fellow billionaire Victor Fung as chairman of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lucky gamblers at Adelson's Venetian casino/resort in Las Vegas hurt first-quarter profits this year, but room rates set records. The son of a Boston cab driver made his fortune selling the Comdex Computer Dealer Expo in 1995, and by buying and demolishing the Sands Hotel to make room for Venetian. "Steve Wynn tells people that I should be credited with teaching Las Vegas how to make money in hotels."

name: Billionaires
bio: Performance for the Janus growth funds might have peaked in 1999, but Bailey's making more than just management fees in the post-Internet econonomy.  Parent company Stillwell Financial just paid him $610 million for half his stake in Janus.  That leaves Bailey with another 6% to sell in the future.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earl Cadogan owns about 90 acres in the upscale Chelsea district of London. The properties have been with the Earl's family for almost 250 years. Thrice married, he is keen on horse racing and has been a strong supporter of leukemia research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited a controlling interest in the SK Group, Korea's 4th largest industrial conglomerate, from his father, the group's founder. Group companies respectively control 37% and 52% of Korea's energy and mobile telecoms markets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a carpenter in northern Portugal owns majority of $5 billion (sales) conglomerate Sonae GSPS, involved in wood products, real estate investments, communications, shopping centers, a daily paper and a radio station. Net worth is down $500 million from a year ago: Shares have been affected by weakness in Portuguese retailing and by the group's Internet segment, Sonae.com, which is suffering.

name: Billionaires
bio: Baron Benjamin took over the Geneva-based family's banking, wine and real estate empire after his father, Edmond, died in 1997. After shrugging off initial concerns about his youth, Baron Benjamin has received high marks for his management of the family's private bank, the Banque Privee Edmond de Rothschild, which is believed to have some $28 billion in assets under management. Like many young Genevans, he loves sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chief executive of USA Networks is the constant subject of rumors that he's scheming big mergers, but so far big conglomerates have eluded him: Currently allied with French giant Vivendi, he's said to have sights on NBC. Most notable recent merger: His February marriage to longtime pal Diane von Furstenburg.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Son of a Ford engineer from Essex, Dixon shunned college to start a hot dog delivery business, but went into baking when he discovered the rolls were in greater demand. Sold the business for $1.4 million in 1988; poured profits into Regus, his fledgling idea to provide big companies with temporary, fully serviced office space. Now operates 300 business centers in 50 countries for corporations like IBM, Microsoft, Coca-Cola, Nokia. The fortune: Regus went public last fall; Dixon owns 61%. Passions: Five children. Kite-flying, windsurfing.

name: Billionaires
bio: The general partner with VC firm Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers made early ? and lucrative ? bets on Amazon, Sun and Netscape.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mallorca-based Escarrer family holds  61% of Sol Melia chain, one of the world's largest hotel groups and Spain's biggest hotelier. The $780 million (revenues) chain started off as one hotel in Majorca in 1956 and now runs over 330 hotels in 30 countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Internet search engine Yahoo with Stanford buddy Jerry Yang and took company public in 1996. Still manages the Web site, focuses on technical issues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family's scrap metal business into a cascade of holdings in media, utilities and oil, through holding companies Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille and Geneva-listed Pargesa Holding. Latest coup: negotiated to swap stake in TV/radio broadcaster RTL for a 25% stake in German media behemoth Bertelsmann, which he can sell to the public in three years. Wine lover, pal of French billionaire Bernard Arnault and workaholic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Immigrated to the U.S. from Nazareth, Israel at age 5. Now runs Platinum Equity, Los Angeles-based buyout firm. Thirty deals since 1995, including voice-systems designer Nextira.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of William Randolph Hearst (d. 1951), media tycoon who built nation's largest newspaper chain. William III broke away from family business, now partner in tech venture-capital firm Kleiner Perkins, on boards of AtHome, Com21, Viewpoints Datalabs. Hearst empire today: 12 dailies (including "houston Chronicle"), 16 magazines (Harper's "Bazaar," "Cosmopolitan"), TV, cable programing (ESPN, Lifetime).

name: Billionaires
bio: The woman: Mother of four also runs three family-owned companies that make up the Axel Johnson Group, founded by her great-grandfather. The fortune: Revenues were approximately $6.5 billion last year; conglomerate  in which group companies focus on food imports to Nordic countries and distribution of industrial products in Europe. In December Spirent of the UK paid $1.6 billion in cash and stock to acquire the group's Maryland-based Hekimian Laboratories, a telecom network fault repair company.

name: Billionaires
bio: He cofounded Sun Microsystems; Khosla is now one of the movers and shakers of the tech world as a general partner in VC firm Kleiner Perkins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger sister of Esther Koplowitz has wisely invested proceeds from sale of her share of Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas to her sister in 1997.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs leading Spanish construction group Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, $3.9 billion (sales) builders of bridges, highways, commercial properties, water treatment plants and more. She owns 29%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Not any harpsichord playing ex-New York City cabbie can raise enough money to start a hedge fund. Fewer still could see their fund perform better than Kovner's Caxton Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Starting out as an oil trader, Krishnan moved into gambling and more recently telecom. Krishnan, who dropped off our list last year, squeaks back on thanks to his telecom company, Maxis Communications, which has been signing up 100,000 subscribers a month. He recently bought out British Telecom's stake in the company for a reported $303 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mining and railroad magnate runs Americas Mining, one of the world's top copper producers. The company was formed recently out of his established Grupo Mexico, Southern Peru Copper, and U.S.-based Asarco, acquired in 1999. When markets allow, plans to take public. In 1999 Grupo Mexico spent hundreds of millions of dollars cleaning up one of the world's worst ecological disasters--the formerly state-owned Cananea mine in Northern Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford- and MIT-educated Lee Hon Chiu recently retired as chairman of family-run real estate company Hysan Development. He was replaced by his cousin Peter Lee, 48. Hurt by a 10% drop in rental income, the company saw its revenues fall 36% and its profits slide 29% to $109 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Unwinding the hedge fund that made him a legend: Tiger Fund now with $1.5 billion in holdings, half of which is Robertson's. At peak, fund had over $22 billion in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man: Founded the Orascom conglomerate, whose construction, telecommunications and tourism divisions are run by his three sons. The fortune: In a joint venture with Swiss cement giant Holderbank, Orascom Construction now controls over 25% of the Egyptian cement market. Orascom Telecom is the leading mobile phone operator throughout Africa and the Middle East, with 2.1 million subscribers. Passions: Relaxing at one of the Orascom Hotel Developments resorts on the Red Sea or the Sinai Peninsula.

name: Billionaires
bio: He built his father's Green Bay-based trucking business into the nation's largest truckload carrier ($3.1 billion revenue). The market downturn may force him to put off plans to spin off Schneider Logistics, a high-tech shipping management operation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of John T. Dorrance, who invented process for condensed soup and bought Campbell Soup from uncle in 1914. Grandchildren together still control nearly 50% of Campbell. Hope's son Archibold runs Campbell's Godiva Chocolate division, only family member still working for firm full time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Singapore's powerful United Overseas Bank chairman has been buying up the holding company of the 300-year-old Tiger Balm empire. Wee also is founder of the Chinese Heritage Centre in Singapore, which with ten sponsors, counts seven current and former FORBES billionaires as members.

name: Billionaires
bio: He left the University of Nebraska for the Merchant Marine Academy; after he graduated, he took over his father's billboard business. White sold his Whiteco Outdoor for $960 million in 1998; he still owns another billboard firm with a big China presence.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Internet search engine Yahoo with Stanford buddy David Filo. IPO 1996. Public face of company, promotes products and services.
